reviewText:
Adam Sandler used to be a good comedian, though some have trouble remembering when. Even I have difficulty believing that only twenty years ago he was at the helm of great comedies like "Billy Madison" and "The Waterboy", entirely due to his recent track record as an actor. In the past few years alone, he's produced and starred in a number of box-office flops like 2011's "Jack and Jill" and the subsequent "That's My Boy". Not only has he failed to make us laugh as his career has gone on but he's also failed to make money, and that's probably why he continues to turn to these formulaic and childish pieces of work, his newest being `Blended'.

Centered around two single parents who meet on an unfortunate blind date, one of which divorced and another grieving over their spouse's death, we see them quite conveniently find their way on a trip to Africa together forced to pose as husband and wife. Sounds stupid, right? Guess what, it is.

Feeling as if its story was plucked from the 80's with today's pop-culture thrown in to make it seem somewhat relevant, it treats the audience as if their stupid, throwing every mindless joke that it can on screen (one of which involving elephants making love). Ridiculous from beginning to end and certainly not in a funny way, it succeeded in making me groan and roll my eyes for two hours straight. Rated PG-13 for crude content, "Blended" is sure to make you cringe.

Nothing too mysterious about this movie. It's just a nice, funny family movie. I believe this is the 3rd time Sanders and Barrymore have made a movie together and this time they have families with them.

Sanders loves to make jokes and this movie full of them. Of course, not all the jokes are funny and very obvious there will be one coming up. Then, many times they may take a joke too far, where it started out funny, but they ended up continuing the joke and it's not as funny as before. An example of this would be Terry Crews singing and dancing scenes out of nowhere appearances. They use Terry throughout the movie to make these funny awaked moment jokes. Yes, the first few times were kind of funny, but after seeing the 3rd to 4th time - I was done! It just got kind of ignoring after that, and trust me, there are way more than 4 times you see this joke! Like double that amount. It's too much!

I really enjoyed the younger family members performances. They knew how to act and make me believe their characters well. Sanders and Barrymore did a great job as always. It's a great family, romantic, and comedy movie all in one. People should definitely see this movie, if they love family movies.

Blended is definitely one of the better Adam Sandler movies in recent years. To me, it had a decent storyline, great comedy, and even some touching moments that'll pull on your heartstrings. This review may have spoilers. Sandler stars as Jim Friedman who goes on a terrible blind date with Drew Barrymore's character, Lauren Reynolds. Both have children of their own. When one thing leads to another, both Jim, Lauren and their families end up at a lovers resort in Africa. They all have a rocky start, but slowly become friends. Lauren helps Jim's daughters and Jim helps Lauren's sons. If you love Adam Sandler movies, you'll definitely love BLENDED!!!

The chemistry between Adam Sandler and Drew Barrymore is great as usual.  They are so cute together.  Drew's character is divorced with a husband who disappoints his son's often while Adam plays a widower with 3 daughters.  Seeing Drew struggle with "boy" issues and Adam struggle with "girl" issues is hysterical and often very poignant.  Adam usually plays a goofball character and this isn't different, however scenes with his daughters dealing with the loss of their mother - he was amazing and not goofy at all.

Terry Crews and Wendy McLendon-Covey steal the show in their scenes - both are outstanding as usual.  The kids are all great as well.

Some "grown up" themes so may not be appropriate for younger kids - but laugh out loud funny and truly touching and heart warming.

It's definitely an Adam sandler/happy Madison film, make no mistake. It's not on par with "Spanglish" as far as a removal from Sandler's general film genre, but it's not as immature as "little Nicky" or "big daddy". It's middle ground...sorta like "Click". As I am writing this, I am surprised how many Sandler films I have seen and how many he has made. This was what I was hoping for though, after this duo made 50 first dates I seriously thought about and checked on any upcoming pairings of Barrymore and Sandler in the future. I like the wedding singer, but it was a lot more immature than "50", and Blended matches 50 for all its good points, heart and ridiculous antics and is possibly a little more mature. I really enjoyed Blended, in fact, I'll buy it and watch it often. The first 15 minutes are what I have been replaying in my head over and over again and laughing aloud. Seriously, this film had some good laughs, and not just between Sandler and Barrymore, but between Barrymore and mclendon-covey they had great banter!
Those two should do a film or several. I loved laughing at the film and I thought the premise and backdrop for the film-an African tourist safari catering to blended families-was really interesting. Sandler was more demure in his typical attitudes, more real it felt and Barrymore gets better looking with age, I wish they would dress her in prettier clothes, she is beautiful and authentically so.
Having started a family since "50 first dates", having kids and complicated families in this film made the actors and story a more enjoyable experience...The blended premise was very appropriate given today's statistics.

I didn't love everything about the film, Sandler always pushes a little too far for my taste, but it wasn't terrible, the film has many redeeming moments and the uncomfortable, embarrassing feeling that Terry crews instills in every moment he is on screen makes it all worth it.

Seriously, just watch this film if you are on the fence, it's a little unusual in the premise, delivers on production quality and is very entertaining.

I had no idea this would be so funny! I loved (and own) the first two Sandler/Barrymore movies, so I was really hopeful with this one - and I wasn't disappointed! Third time was definitely a charm!

Blended is a funny, heartwarming movie that had me howling at times: the blind date...the drugstore scene...the parking lot conversation...and pretty much the rest of the movie. Sometimes I find Sandler to be a bit too raunchy for my taste, and sometimes Barrymore seems to be reciting lines rather than acting - but they were both great in this movie. The chemistry between the two was the best yet.

"Lauren" (Barrymore) is a divorced, flustered mom raising two out-of-control boys on her own, and "Jim" (Sandler) is the widowed, slightly bewildered dad raising three girls as tomboys. After a disastrous blind date they can't stand each other, but ironically find themselves vacationing together in Africa on a "blended family" retreat. Each parent bonds with the other's kids, as Lauren provides the mothering that the girls are missing, and Jim gives the boys the attention and guidance they aren't getting from their father. And, of course, Jim and Lauren fall for each other in the process.

This is a really heartwarming movie. When I wasn't howling with laughter I was smiling and misting up a little. This is far and away the best Barrymore movie I have ever seen, and Sandler's toned-down, loveable dad role is adorable. There's still plenty of snark, innuendo, and mishaps, though, to keep me smirking - it IS Adam Sandler, after all! But overall this was a great family movie that was genuinely touching and funny.

Sometimes (make that half the time) Adam Sandler films are average at best and the humor misses the mark, however Blended is thankfully NOT one of those films.  This is mostly due to the pacing of the comedy being less outrageous than usual, giving viewers time to appreciate each moment instead of forcing an excessively outrageous variety of humor down our throats.  Not that fast-paced comedy is bad, even in other Adam Sandler movies, but the slower delivery of Blended compliments solid writing to make for a decent comedy with elements of romance.

Drew Barrymore.  It's hard to believe she's the same woman I remember being a kid back in the 80's.  She barely resembles the same girl what with being an adult now.  Only occasionally do I still see glimpses of the same girl.  Anyway Blended is about Adam Sandler and Drew Barrymore going on a blind date together (which is how the film starts- getting right to the point was a good idea in this case) at a um... naughty restaurant much to Drew's dislike, and the whole date turns into a disaster rather quickly when it's apparent Adam cares more about the sports event taking place on the TV behind Drew than he does a potential relationship with Drew.

However fate is a mysterious thing- they eventually meet up again at the downtown pharmacy by chance.  Adam needs to pick up tampons for his oldest of 3 daughters, and Drew needs to replace her oldest son's naughty girl magazine after she immaturely rips it apart.  The humor is really good during this segment- every joke is hilarious (including the ones by the cashier lady).  Soon after Adam has to make a trip to Drew's house to drop off a credit card that mistakenly got in his bag at the pharmacy parking lot (since they both felt ashamed for the things they were purchasing so they did a switcheroo).  Well one thing leads to another and eventually Adam and his 3 daughters along with Drew and her 2 sons take a trip to Africa... but they didn't take the trip together.  It was another coincidence.  What I find interesting about the story are all the striking similarities both Drew and Adam share but the story never acknowledges it outright- more like Adam and Drew take these coincidences as hints they belong together.  But neither one wants to admit they belong together.  They're both pretty stubborn.

This film is basically a wild adventure through Africa type of vacation film, but the humor and writing is constantly terrific.  More characters join in once they arrive to Africa such as a big-breasted luscious lady and her joyful husband (and they have a son that Adam's oldest daughter finds attractive).  A big theme throughout the movie is that Adam prefers to dress his daughters like boys due to his love of sports, so they get mistaken as boys.  Most of the characters except Adam's middle daughter get a fair amount of attention.  I guess Jane... er, the middle sibling is always the one who gets the least amount of attention anyway.  She has a habit of believing that her mother is still alive so she likes to pretend she's communicating with an invisible person.  That's her theme.

The youngest daughter is there to show viewers how much she resembles a young Drew Barrymore (adorable and smart).  As for Drew's sons, well the oldest one has an attitude and loves the ladies as evident by the girly magazine under his bed, and the youngest one takes swinging and missing at baseball pitches personally- he throws his bat and helmet, and even kicks the dirt screaming.  Basically Adam teaches him to swing better.  Other times the wild vacation aspects come in as, for example, Adam and Drew's younger son go ostrich riding and Drew Barrymore herself takes to the skies which leads to a hilarious rhinoceros scene.  Another memorable character is Drew's workmate played by Wendi McLendon Covey who tends to act bitter towards men.  I won't spoil anything, but the trip home from Africa ends on different terms than I was expecting.

Overall Blended is a great film.  I won't mention all the outrageous things that happen when Drew and Adam's family take a tour to Africa, but the story is told sensibly without ever being overbearing in the comedy department, and many of the jokes are light-hearted enough to be appropriate for teens (but not quite kids).  This movie is WAY better than that other Adam Sandler film (what was it, Grown Ups?  That movie was awful!)  Overall highly recommended.

So I was invited/encouraged/forced to watch this movie during the holidays, as we had 14 guests in (two families with five kids apiece), and both started raving about the greatest, most hysterical movie in the history of stuff . . Blended! "Certainly," thought I, "they can't be talking about the Sandler/Barrymore movie?" Alas, they were. I decided to sit through it to earn points with the wife. Did it work? Time will tell.

Given my ankle-high expectations, two or three stars seems about right. I'm feeling generous, so three it is. "Blended" isn't aggressively awful, and it's not really even "bad" compared to, say, a lot of the stuff served up on the Disney Channel. Unfortunately, it's also not "good". More to the point, it's the bleedin' definition of "generic." Is "extraordinarily average" a thing? It is now. It may occupy your attention for a couple of hours. If you have any expectations beyond that, (and why in the world would you . . it's a Sandler/Barrymore movie) and you have even a slight interest in film, you're going to be grumpy afterwards.

Setups for completely predictable confidence-boosting transformations of the Sandler character's kids? Check. Cheap PG-13 gross-out gags inserted every five minutes? Check. Pratfalls aplenty? Check. Improbably "zany" characters inserted into scenes now and then only because the director decides "well, this is dragging . . time for a big laugh I guess . . Terry and/or Kevin! Go do zany stuff!!" Check . . too damn many checks in that department, matter of fact. Unnecessary "bad guy" trying to mess up everyone's good vibes near the end? Check. Valuable lessons learned by all by the end? Check.

So, I love my family, but good LORD they gots no taste in movies. Not "bad" taste -- no taste, and there's a difference. They just have no idea that movies can offer more than a few harmless chuckles for two hours. Nor do they care. I just wish that some future Christmas I'll be "allowed" to choose the movie we watch together. I've sat patiently through enough processed cheese to make nachos for half the United States. Is there no end to my suffering? I've been good . . I just gave a non-Punch Drunk Love Adam Sandler movie three stars! I've suppressed my inner snob as much as I can! PLEASE GOD, THROW ME A BONE!!

As a huge fan of The Wedding Singer, I have been hesitant to watch Blended because Adam Sandler's past few movies haven't been worth my time. I do really like Drew Barrymore though, and opted to give Blended a try. I'd like to say this movie was perfect, but there are some scenes that had me wanting to pull my hair out. It's better than he's done in a long time, but still had annoying moments that made it hard to love it.

The Plot

Drew plays a single mom, her husband cheated on her, thus ending their marriage. Her sons pay heavily for their dad's attitudes. He's happy coming and going when it suits his schedule, even if it means disappointing his sons repeatedly. Drew owns her own closet organizing company with a friend. Following a horrible blind date with Adam Sandler (he took her to a Hooters of all places), Drew is ready to give up on dating, while her best friend announces that she's in love. When Drew's ex cancels a rafting trip he'd been planning with their sons, she decides to fill in and provide her sons with spring break memories they won't forget.

Adam plays a widower with three daughters. Beyond the disaster of a date with Drew, his job at Dick's Sporting Goods happens to link him to her anyway, as his boss is the guy Drew's business partner is falling in love with. Adam has a hard time letting his little girls grow up, even though his oldest is 15 and ready to get out of the tomboy phase her father has locked her into. His girls are also sick of spring break camping trips and hope for something different this year.

When Drew's friend learns her boyfriend has five kids and plans to bring them with them on their non-refundable trip to Africa, she dumps him. This leaves the trip to Africa up for grabs. Drew immediately asks her friend to get her a ticket and two kids tickets, and Adam learns of the cancelled trip and asks his boss for tickets for himself and his three girls.

Upon their arrival in Africa, they find they're going to have to share the gigantic family suite together and decide to make the most of it. The more time they spend together, the more the children start to benefit from this unexpected blending, and the question arises if there is love in the cards after all.

The Chemistry

To me there is no doubt that Sandler and Barrymore, however unexpected, have some of the best on-screen chemistry there is today. I love them together. That said, the kids work really well in this too. Drew gets to show off her maternal side, and it's not surprising that Adam is the father figure, albeit a wacky one, the boys so desperately need.

The Downfall

Here's the one issue I had. Once they are in Africa, there is an a cappella group and their lead, played by Terry Crews (former NFLer). They make random appearances where Crews breaks out into some corny song that usually becomes a launch pad for him to be sexually suggestive. I grew really, really tired of this. It broke up the movie's flow and did nothing to enhance the storyline. I'd love to watch this again after editing out those unnecessary sections. I think with a few scenes taken out, this could be my favorite rom-com between Sandler and Barrymore.
